title: Big-Ticket Condo Buyers Gradually Returning to Manhattan’s Luxury Market
text:
Manhattan’s lackluster luxury real estate market showed a little improvement leading into the long Labor Day weekend, as two more big-tickets condos found buyers during the unofficial last week of the summer, according to Monday’s Olshan Report.



High-value deals have plummeted since the increase to the city’s mansion and transfer taxes went into effect July 1, effectively raising the cost of buying a home over $2 million.



More: Alex Rodriguez Sells Hollywood Hills Home With Architectural Pedigree for $4.4M

The immediate aftermath of the hike was almost a month without a single deal over $10 million in Manhattan, and super-prime condo buyers willing to spend eight figures or more appeared to avoid the market altogether.



Until the tail-end of August, the Manhattan market had gone for two months without a single apartment deal over $10 million.



There were 16 contracts signed for $4 million or more—the report’s benchmark for luxury—across Manhattan in the week ending Sunday, “a standard-issue total for the week leading into Labor Day,” wrote Donna Olshan, president of Olshan Realty and author of the report.



The total value of contracts signed last week was $118.39 million, roughly $9 million less than the week before.



The priciest contract signed was on a penthouse at 50 United Nations Plaza, asking $18.25 million. The 5,893-square-foot condo has five bedrooms, two staff rooms, a library and views over the East River.



The second most expensive deal was for a unit at Midtown’s 90-story One57, last asking $17.5 million, reduced from $19 million. The four-bedroom condo spans 3,466 square feet and has views of Central Park.

Of the 16 contracts signed last week, 13 were condos, two were co-ops and one was a condop; no luxury townhouses entered contract.



An unusually high number of high-priced townhouses have transacted in recent weeks as sellers appear more willing to negotiate on price. Until two weeks ago, townhouses had accounted for all the highest priced deals since June.
